message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Consistent Individual Behavioral Variation: What Do We Know and Where Are We Going?
Paper Abstract: The study of individual behavioral variation, sometimes called animal personalities or behavioral types, is now a well-established area of research in behavioral ecology and evolution. Considerable theoretical work has developed predictions about its ecological and evolutionary causes and consequences, and studies testing these theories continue to grow. Here, we synthesize the current empirical work to shed light on which theories are well supported and which need further refinement. We find that the major frameworks explaining the existence of individual behavioral variation, the pace-of-life syndrome hypothesis and state-dependent feedbacks models, have mixed support. The consequences of individual behavioral variation are well studied at the individual level but less is known about consequences at higher levels such as among species and communities. The focus of this review is to reevaluate and reestablish the foundation of individual behavioral variation research: What do we know? What questions remain? And where are we going next?
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "animal personality"

Links: [{"title":"Personality in animals - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personality_in_animals"},{"title":"The Animal in You - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Animal_in_You"},{"title":"Animal stereotype - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Animal_stereotype"},{"title":"Big Five - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_Five"},{"title":"Personal grooming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personal_grooming"},{"title":"Monkey (zodiac) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monkey_(zodiac)"}]

## Search Results for "Animal Personality"

Here are the key findings:

### Definition and Research

Animal personality is defined as individual differences in behaviour that are consistent across time and ecological context.(no content)The study of animal personality is largely based on the observation and investigation of behavioural traits, which often examine characteristics such as aggressiveness, avoidance of novelty, boldness, exploration and sociality.

### Historical Development

Russian physiologist Ivan Pavlov was one of the first researchers to integrate personality into his research of animal behaviour, categorizing the behaviour of dogs as Excitable, Lively, Quiet or Inhibited.(no content)The first study that empirically examined animal personality was done in 1938, when Meredith Crawford quantified individual differences in the behaviour of young chimpanzees using a behaviour rating scale.

### Current Research

Research on animal personality variation has been burgeoning since the mid 1990s.(no content)The diversity of animal personality can be compared in cross-species studies, demonstrating its pervasiveness in the evolutionary process of animals.

## Overview of Behavioral Ecology

Behavioral ecology is the study of the evolutionary basis for animal behavior due to ecological pressures.(no content)It is a major subfield of both ecology and evolutionary biology that incorporates both ecological and evolutionary principles to analyze the ways in which animal behavior has evolved, and the ways in which animals use behavior to solve social and ecological problems.

## Key Concepts

Behavioral ecology emerged from ethology after Niko Tinbergen outlined four questions to address when studying animal behaviors: what are the proximate causes, ontogeny, survival value, and phylogeny of a behavior?

A central concept in behavioral ecology is adaptive significance. If an organism has a trait that provides a selective advantage in its environment, then natural selection favors it. Adaptive significance refers to the expression of a trait that affects fitness, measured by an individual's reproductive success.

## Areas of Study

Key topics in behavioral ecology include:

- Evolution of aggression, mating behavior, parental care, communication, and the complexities of living in groups and families.
- Adaptive behavior, which includes any behavior that contributes directly or indirectly to an individual's reproductive success. Examples include favoring kin in altruistic behaviors, sexual selection of the most fit mate, and defending a territory or harem from rivals.

## Human Behavioral Ecology

Human behavioral ecology applies the principles of evolutionary theory and optimization to the study of human behavioral and cultural diversity.

## Overview of Behavioral Ecology

Behavioral ecology is the study of the evolutionary basis for animal behavior due to ecological pressures.(no content)It is a major subfield of both ecology and evolutionary biology that incorporates both ecological and evolutionary principles to analyze the ways in which animal behavior has evolved, and the ways in which animals use behavior to solve social and ecological problems.

## Key Concepts

Behavioral ecology emerged from ethology after Niko Tinbergen outlined four questions to address when studying animal behaviors: what are the proximate causes, ontogeny, survival value, and phylogeny of a behavior?

A central concept in behavioral ecology is adaptive significance. If an organism has a trait that provides a selective advantage in its environment, then natural selection favors it. Adaptive significance refers to the expression of a trait that affects fitness, measured by an individual's reproductive success.

## Areas of Study

Key topics in behavioral ecology include:

- Evolution of aggression, mating behavior, parental care, communication, and the complexities of living in groups and families.
- Adaptive behavior, which includes any behavior that contributes directly or indirectly to an individual's reproductive success. Examples include favoring kin in altruistic behaviors, sexual selection of the most fit mate, and defending a territory or harem from rivals.

## Human Behavioral Ecology

Human behavioral ecology applies the principles of evolutionary theory and optimization to the study of human behavioral and cultural diversity.

I've found comprehensive information about the evolution of animal behavior. Here's what the search revealed:

## Overview

Behavioral ecology is the study of the evolutionary basis for animal behavior due to ecological pressures.(no content)Darwin's theory of evolution by natural selection is the only scientific explanation for why an animal's behaviour is usually well adapted for survival and reproduction in its environment.

## Key Scientific Fields

Ethology is a branch of zoology that studies the behaviour of non-human animals. It has its scientific roots in the work of Charles Darwin and of American and German ornithologists of the late 19th and early 20th century. The modern discipline of ethology is generally considered to have begun during the 1930s with the work of the Dutch biologist Nikolaas Tinbergen and the Austrian biologists Konrad Lorenz and Karl von Frisch.

## Natural Selection and Adaptation

If an organism has a trait that provides a selective advantage in its environment, then natural selection favors it. Adaptive significance refers to the expression of a trait that affects fitness, measured by an individual's reproductive success. Adaptive traits are those that produce more copies of the individual's genes in future generations.

## Evolution of Cooperative Behavior

Interestingly, there have been multiple hypotheses for the evolution of cooperation, all of which are rooted in Hamilton's models based on inclusive fitness. These models hypothesize that cooperation is favored by natural selection due to either direct fitness benefits (mutually beneficial cooperation) or indirect fitness benefits (altruistic cooperation).

Based on the web search results, here's information about state-dependent behavior:

## State-Dependent Memory and Behavior

State-dependent memory or state-dependent learning is the phenomenon where people remember more information if their physical or mental state is the same at time of encoding and time of recall.

### How It Works

While state-dependent memory may seem rather similar to context-dependent memory, context-dependent memory involves an individual's external environment and conditions (such as the room used for study and to take the test) while state-dependent memory applies to the individual's internal conditions (such as use of substances or mood).

### Examples with Drugs

Research has demonstrated this effect across various substances. State-dependent learning refers to the finding that people recall more information when their physiological state is the same at encoding and retrieval. For example, people who undergo alcohol intoxication while encoding information recall significantly more when they are also intoxicated during retrieval, compared to those whose alcoholic states differ from encoding to retrieval.(no content)The state-dependent effect has also been generalized to a variety of drugs, including morphine, cigarettes, scopolamine, and nitric oxide.

### Mood-Dependent Effects

State-dependent behavior also extends to mood. When a person is depressed they find it nearly impossible to think of a time in the past when they were happy. The longer they were depressed the more impossible the task became.

This phenomenon has important implications for understanding how our internal states influence our ability to recall information and perform learned behaviors.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about life history evolution:

## Life History Theory

Life history theory (LHT) is an analytical framework designed to study the diversity of life history strategies used by different organisms throughout the world, as well as the causes and results of the variation in their life cycles.(no content)It is a theory of biological evolution that seeks to explain aspects of organisms' anatomy and behavior by reference to the way that their life histories—including their reproductive development and behaviors, post-reproductive behaviors, and lifespan—have been shaped by natural selection.

## Key Components

A life history strategy is the "age- and stage-specific patterns" and timing of events that make up an organism's life, such as birth, weaning, maturation, death, etc. These events, notably juvenile development, age of sexual maturity, first reproduction, number of offspring and level of parental investment, senescence and death, depend on the physical and ecological environment of the organism.

## Development and Focus

The theory was developed in the 1950s and is used to answer questions about topics such as organism size, age of maturation, number of offspring, life span, and many others.

## Diversity of Strategies

Organisms have evolved a great variety of life histories, from Pacific salmon, which produce thousands of eggs at one time and then die, to human beings, who produce a few offspring over the course of decades.

Links: [{"title":"Life history theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Life_history_theory"},{"title":"History of life - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_life"},{"title":"Timeline of the evolutionary history of life","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_the_evolutionary_history_of_life"},{"title":"Evolutionary ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_ecology"},{"title":"Timeline of the evolutionary history of life - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_evolution"},{"title":"Life history - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Life_history"},{"title":"Timeline of human evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_human_evolution"},{"title":"Evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution"},{"title":"Abiogenesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abiogenesis"},{"title":"History of Earth - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Earth"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about life history evolution:

## Life History Theory

Life history theory (LHT) is an analytical framework designed to study the diversity of life history strategies used by different organisms throughout the world, as well as the causes and results of the variation in their life cycles.(no content)It is a theory of biological evolution that seeks to explain aspects of organisms' anatomy and behavior by reference to the way that their life histories—including their reproductive development and behaviors, post-reproductive behaviors, and lifespan—have been shaped by natural selection.

## Key Components

A life history strategy is the "age- and stage-specific patterns" and timing of events that make up an organism's life, such as birth, weaning, maturation, death, etc. These events, notably juvenile development, age of sexual maturity, first reproduction, number of offspring and level of parental investment, senescence and death, depend on the physical and ecological environment of the organism.

## Development and Focus

The theory was developed in the 1950s and is used to answer questions about topics such as organism size, age of maturation, number of offspring, life span, and many others.

## Diversity of Strategies

Organisms have evolved a great variety of life histories, from Pacific salmon, which produce thousands of eggs at one time and then die, to human beings, who produce a few offspring over the course of decades.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
